description:
Human polyomavirus 9 (HPyV9) is a member of the Polyomaviridae family, a group of small, non-enveloped DNA viruses. HPyV9 was first discovered in 2011 in the blood of an immunosuppressed patient, and it has since been detected in various human samples, including skin, respiratory, and gastrointestinal specimens.

The HPyV9 genome is a circular, double-stranded DNA molecule of approximately 5,000 base pairs. The viral genome encodes for several key proteins, including the large T antigen and small T antigen, which play crucial roles in viral replication and host cell manipulation.

Seroepidemiological studies have suggested that HPyV9 infection is relatively common in the general population, with a worldwide seroprevalence ranging from 40% to 80% in adults. However, the clinical significance of HPyV9 infection remains largely unknown, as the virus has not been conclusively linked to any specific human disease.

Research on HPyV9 is ongoing, and further studies are needed to elucidate its potential role in human health and disease, as well as its prevalence, transmission, and interactions with the human host.
